site_title: NTUC conference backs wage model, PME push
summary: The National Trades Union Congress (NTUC) has reaffirmed its support for the progressive wage model (PWM) and the push to recruit more professionals, managers and executives (PMEs) into the labour movement. The PWM aims to help workers achieve sustainable wage increases through tailored wage ladders. Delegates also called for increased training support, stronger engagement with management and government agencies, and a "whole of labour movement" approach to develop a strong core of labour leaders. With membership nearing one million by 2015, the labour movement sees the PWM and PME recruitment as key strategies for long-term growth and development.

site_title: Bank of Japan's board split on inflation target
summary: The Bank of Japan's policy board split on whether the central bank can achieve its 2% inflation target in fiscal 2014, but the majority stuck to the target. Three members dissented, citing downside risks to the economy. The BOJ maintained its massive monetary stimulus and pledged to reach its target, despite IMF officials expressing doubts. The central bank also revised its growth forecast to 1.5% for FY2014, citing robust exports and a fiscal spending pledge by the government.

site_title: China Minzhong Q1 profit tumbles 60%
summary: China Minzhong, a vegetable processor, reported a 60% plunge in net profit to 48.4 million yuan (S$9.8 million) for the first quarter ended September 30, 2013. The company cited higher operating costs, mostly labor, and lower average selling prices as factors. Despite this, revenue edged up 4% to 637.8 million yuan. Majority shareholder Indofood Sukses Makmur made a general offer for the company following allegations of fraud and financial irregularities. China Minzhong plans to mitigate pressure through higher-value products and efficient resource use.

site_title: Three-Minute Digest
summary: Singapore firms Pontiac Land Group and GIC's property arm have announced major overseas investments, with Pontiac investing in a New York City property and GIC's arm investing in Jakarta.

site_title: Around Town
summary: Three shows are set to be performed in Singapore: A Christmas Carol by Canada's Dufflebag Theatre Company, musical versions of Grimm's fairy tales by the Drama Centre, and Little Red Riding Hood by the Singapore Repertory Theatre. The Merchants of Bollywood musical returns to Marina Bay Sands Grand Theatre from November 5, while a Journey to the Soul Mountain exhibition showcases 50 black-and-white photos taken by Nobel Prize winner Gao Xingjian. A group exhibition, Humans Among Aliens, features works by three contemporary Italian artists until November 17.

site_title: Brighter power sector with solar energy
summary: Singapore is diversifying its energy mix with a focus on solar power, aiming to meet up to 10% of peak electricity demand. The power industry is stable, with natural gas supplies abundant and renewable energy expected to supplement electricity generation. Despite increased competition and efficiency gains, electricity tariffs have not decreased, but smart meters and alternative fuel sources are being introduced to address supply security for big consumers and households.

site_title: CDLHT's Q3 DPU falls 2.9% to 2.64 cents
summary: CDL Hospitality Trust (CDLHT) reported a distribution per stapled security of 2.64 cents for Q3, down 2.9% from the previous year, due to lower income available for distribution and a 2.2% decline in gross revenue. Net property income fell 1.7% to $33 million, primarily due to weaker Singapore hotel revenue and the Australian dollar's weakened value. The company's annualised distribution yield is 6.23%. Despite this, CIMB maintains a neutral call on CDLHT, citing a strong balance sheet and potential for accretive acquisitions.

site_title: China writer in exile tackles problems that affect most people
summary: Nobel Prize-winning author Gao Xingjian, a Chinese writer in exile, has spoken about the impact of politics on his work. Despite distancing himself from politics, his writings often reflect the complexities of Chinese politics. Gao's work has been banned in China, but he has received international recognition, including the Nobel Prize in Literature in 2000. He will attend the Singapore Writers Festival, where he will premiere his third film, Requiem for Beauty, and deliver a lecture on literature and aesthetics.

site_title: Good Class Bungalow market starts to thaw
summary: The Good Class Bungalow (GCB) market in Singapore appears to be thawing after a quiet period following the introduction of the Total Debt Servicing Ratio framework in June. At least two properties have recently been sold, with a Gallop Park bungalow changing hands for $25.2 million and a Dalvey Road property selling for $33 million. Several other properties are currently for sale, including a Mount Echo Park bungalow with an indicative price of around $26.8 million. Market watchers predict that prices will rise again in Q3 next year, with a dozen potential buyers looking to purchase a GCB for their own residence.

site_title: Much of 777X design work to be outside Seattle
summary: Boeing will place a significant amount of design work for its 777X jetliner in cities outside Seattle, including Charleston, South Carolina, Huntsville, Alabama, and Philadelphia. The move, confirmed by Boeing, is seen as a blow to engineering workers in Washington state and may lead to jobs migrating to non-union states. The company aims to bring engineering skill from across the company to tackle the 777X project, citing lessons learned from previous programs.

site_title: Soilbuild Reit's DPU of 0.76 cent above forecast
summary: Soilbuild Business Space Reit posted a better-than-expected distribution per unit (DPU) of 0.76 cent, exceeding its forecast of 0.738 cent. The payout is 3% higher and results in an annualized DPU of 6.03 cents, with an 8% annualized dividend yield. The company's distributable income was $6.1 million, gross revenue was $8.2 million, and net property income was $6.9 million, all higher than forecast. Soilbuild Reit's gearing stood at 29.4%, below the forecast of 29.9%.

site_title: Jobless rate at lowest since last Dec
summary: The jobless rate in Singapore fell to 1.8% in September, the lowest level since December 2012, as layoffs subsided in the third quarter. Despite a slowdown from the previous quarter, employment growth remained strong, driven by the services and construction sectors. The unemployment rate for Singapore citizens dropped to 2.8% from 3.1% in June, while the number of unemployed residents decreased to 48,300. Redundancies fell to 2,600 workers in Q3, offsetting a doubling in contract workers.

images.alt_text: The jobless rate surprisingly fell to 1.8 per cent in September - the lowest level since last December - as layoffs subsided in the third quarter, preliminary official figures released yesterday showed. Employment growth remained strong, driven mainly by the services and construction sectors, despite slowing from the previous quarter - PHOTO: BLOOMBERG

site_title: Company Briefs
summary: Creative Technology posted a net loss of US$5.54 million for its Q1, a 24% increase from the previous year. Turnover fell 15% to US$30.4 million. Pure Beauty's offer for SMG is now unconditional after 62.57% of shares were accepted. Loyz Energy drew first oil in a US well, while Yongnam Holdings warned of an operating loss for Q3 due to cost overruns. Cosco delivered a bulk carrier to an Asian buyer, and Tianjin Zhong Xin's Q3 net profit dropped 6% due to a subsidiary disposal.

site_title: 'No threat' to fair trading in Sky One, says SGX
summary: Singapore Exchange (SGX) has found no threat to fair trading in the sharp drop of Sky One Holdings stock, contrary to regulators' actions on other affected stocks. A review of trading in Asiasons Capital, Blumont Group, and LionGold Corp showed "a lack of transparency" that could have threatened fair trading. SGX stated that trading curbs were not necessary for Sky One, a logistics provider undergoing a reverse takeover, and that the lack of transparency in its case was not severe enough to warrant a suspension.

site_title: Debunking myths and exposing lies
summary: Chinese author Jung Chang spent 12 years researching lesser-known facts about Mao Zedong, debunking myths and exposing lies in her book "Mao: The Unknown Story." The book, published in 2005, showed Mao in a less favorable light, sparking criticism from China. Despite criticism, Chang's books have been translated into over 40 languages and sold millions of copies worldwide. Chang continues to dismiss criticism, citing her meticulous research process and lack of factual errors in her books. She is set to discuss her works at the Singapore Writers Festival, exploring the lives of Mao and Empress Dowager Cixi.

site_title: A new generation, but the same traditions
summary: Domaine Faiveley, a Burgundy winery, has welcomed its new head, Erwan Faiveley, son of the company's founder Francois Faiveley, who took over in 2007. Erwan aims to build on the company's traditions and reputation. This is part of a trend in the wine industry, where the next generation of family members are taking over family-owned businesses, such as Domaines Drouhin and Louis Jadot, ensuring the continuation of their honor, reputation, and integrity.

site_title: Blue chips shield market amid penny storm
summary: Singapore's total market capitalization fell 0.4% to $913.2 billion in October, but large-cap stocks, or "blue chips," helped stabilize the market. Despite a weaker performance, the market is up 7% from last year. DMG & Partners' Terence Wong attributed the resilience of large caps to their ability to "save the day."

site_title: Waving the corporate governance flag
summary: The Securities Investors Association (Singapore) is hosting the fourth Singapore Corporate Governance (CG) Week 2013 from November 8 to 15, with support from the Accounting and Corporate Regulatory Authority, Singapore Accountancy Commission, and the Singapore Exchange. To date, 75 companies have signed a statement of support for good corporate governance standards, which aims to enhance shareholder value and stability of the financial markets. The initiative emphasizes the importance of corporate governance in promoting a healthy economy.

site_title: ANA, Boeing reach 787 grounding deal
summary: ANA Holdings Inc, the world's largest operator of the Boeing 787 Dreamliner, reached a deal with Boeing Co to compensate for grounding the planes after battery fires. The agreement was reached in a confidential discussion, but ANA expects to receive four more 787s by the end of March, bringing its total to 27. The deal follows the grounding of the planes for over three months.

site_title: Solar-powered family car coming soon?
summary: A Dutch student team, Solar Team Eindhoven, has developed a solar-powered family car called Stella, which can produce more energy than it uses and be sold back to the power grid. Stella has a carbon fibre body, long sloping roof of solar panels, and can travel 450 km on a full charge, with an average speed of 67 km/h in the 2013 World Solar Challenge. The team hopes to find a manufacturer to produce Stella, which could revolutionize the automotive industry with an energy-positive vehicle.

site_title: Six events to make time for
summary: British philosopher A C Grayling will deliver a lecture titled "A Good Life in a Bad World" at the Drama Theatre at School of the Arts on November 1, 2013, at 2:30-3:30 pm. Tickets cost $20.

site_title: Asian Masters returns for the fourth year
summary: Asian Masters, a gastronomic fair, returns for its fourth year from October 31 to December 7. The event features two-Michelin-starred chefs, including Chef Mok Kit Keung and Chef Hajime Yoneda, and renowned chefs from Asia and around the world. Wine pairing dinners and master workshops will be held throughout the month, with a charity dinner on November 28 featuring a menu from Unlisted Collection Group chefs, with funds raised going to various charities. Reservations and ticket purchases can be made through the official website or hotline.

site_title: Jaya's Q1 net profit falls 24% to US$7.6m
summary: Jaya Holdings reported a 24% fall in Q1 net profit to US$7.6 million, primarily due to non-recurring items and a vessel sale gain. Excluding these, the profit was 15% higher than the previous quarter. The company delivered two vessels and utilized its existing fleet more effectively.

site_title: CapitaLand's Q3 profit falls amid lower margin
summary: CapitaLand's Q3 net profit fell 8.7% to $135.5 million, despite a 52.5% year-over-year revenue surge to $1.05 billion. Revenue growth was driven by increased contributions from four core business units and higher sales from development projects in Australia and Vietnam. However, the company's cost of sales and other expenses increased, resulting in a 4.1% fall in gross profit. CEO Lim Ming Yan emphasized the company's focus on integrated and mixed developments in China and Singapore, citing a positive outlook for the property market in both countries.

site_title: M1 launches showcase for enterprise apps
summary: M1 launches the Future Lab, a showcase for enterprise apps, to cater to businesses. The lab, located at M1's regional operating centre, allows executives to test various apps, including those for remote control of smart home devices and fleet management. M1 is also sponsoring an app development contest for Ngee Ann Poly students. This move aims to strengthen M1's presence in the enterprise app market, differentiating itself from competitors SingTel and StarHub.

site_title: Litigator and author Adrian Tan joins Stamford Law
summary: Litigator and author Adrian Tan, 47, has left Drew & Napier after 21 years to join Stamford Law, a boutique firm led by prominent corporate lawyer Lee Suet Fern. Tan, known for high-profile cases and his humorous writings, cited Stamford's international lawyer hires and bold approach to the market as the reason for his departure. Stamford Law's senior director, Mrs Lee, welcomed Tan, praising his litigation capabilities and community service. The move is seen as a significant boost to Stamford Law's disputes practice, and Tan is expected to bring his skills and wit to the firm.

site_title: Airbus will deliver at least 25 A380s a year: CEO
summary: Airbus has reaffirmed its goal to deliver at least 25 A380s per year in 2013, despite a lack of new orders, and has set a target of reaching breakeven on the program by 2015 based on an average delivery rate of 30 aircraft per year. The company's CEO, Fabrice Bregier, stated that he has no intention of reducing production below 25 aircraft per year, but acknowledged that the target of reaching breakeven by 2015 would be harder to achieve at this rate.

site_title: Key URA man quits to move to private sector
summary: Marc Boey, a key policymaker at the Urban Redevelopment Authority (URA), is leaving the civil service to join the private sector after 19 years of experience. Boey, 46, will be replaced by Sin Lye Chong, who will retain his current posts. Boey played a crucial role in shaping the country's cooling measures and advised on government land sales and property research. Industry experts praise Boey for his balanced views and ability to engage with various stakeholders, including developers and analysts.

site_title: Five industrial sites at Tuas, Gambas Crescent on offer
summary: Five industrial sites in Tuas and Gambas Crescent were released for tender through the Industrial Government Land Sales Programme. Four sites, including three in Tuas and one in Gambas Crescent, are available for confirmed list tenders with prices ranging from $75-140 psf ppr. The fifth site, Parcel 4 at Gambas Crescent, is being offered through the reserve list with a minimum bid price to be determined. Tenders close on December 12 for the Tuas sites and December 10 for the Gambas Crescent site.

site_title: US spy game puts friendships on the line
summary: US spy agencies have been secretly gathering intelligence on world leaders, including friends, sparking outrage globally. The revelations, including US spying on German Chancellor Angela Merkel, have damaged trust and strained relationships with allies. The Obama administration should consider a moratorium on spying on friends, and vice versa, to prevent further harm to international cooperation and national security. The scope and scale of US operations have raised concerns, with the cancellation of a meeting between President Obama and Brazilian President Dilma Rousseff and potential impacts on cooperation between intelligence agencies.

site_title: Clarifying SGX's clarification
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) has issued a clarification to address misconceptions about its role as frontline market regulator. The exchange's powers are limited to issuing warning signals, including queries, designations, and suspension, if trading takes an unusual turn. The signals are intended to maintain discipline and order in daily trading. The clarification aims to provide clarity on the exchange's role and governance, making it compulsory reading for those interested in regulatory matters. The move comes after tumultuous events involving speculative stocks Asiasons, Blumont, and LionGold.

site_title: NTUC aims for breakthrough in raising wages
summary: The National Trades Union Congress (NTUC) aims to make 2014 a "breakthrough" year for low-wage workers in Singapore, with a goal to raise earnings of 100,000 workers. NTUC plans to expand its membership to include professionals, managers, and executives and extend tripartism from the national level to industries. The labour movement is working towards its 2015 vision of "Better Jobs for All" and "Labour Movement for All" and "Tripartism for All".

site_title: No guaranteed access for Pavilion to SLNG terminal
summary: Pavilion Energy, a Temasek-owned firm, will not have guaranteed access to the Singapore LNG terminal. Minister S Iswaran stated that Pavilion will have to compete with other industry players, including international ones, for terminal use. This will be a "level playing field," according to Iswaran. The minister also clarified that Pavilion and SLNG will likely be independent entities, with no guaranteed stake in each other.

site_title: Brad Little stands tall in musical theatre scene
summary: Brad Little, 49, holds the record for playing the Phantom in "The Phantom of the Opera" nearly 2,400 times, making him one of a select group of performers to achieve this feat. Little cherishes the role, which has helped people, including himself, address insecurities. He will star in "The Phantom Unmasked" at Marina Bay Sands, a musical concert featuring songs from various Broadway shows, showcasing his versatility beyond his iconic role.

site_title: Go with an open mind to the works of these two choreographers
summary: Choreographers Christina Chan and Kinsun Chan are set to showcase their works at the upcoming Passages Contemporary Season by the Singapore Dance Theatre. Christina Chan's 15-minute male duet, Shift or Go, will feature a table as a prop. The event encourages audiences to approach the performance with an open mind, free from preconceptions. This approach allows the choreographers to express their unique style and artistic vision without influence from external expectations.

site_title: Tuan Sing Q3 earnings down 52%
summary: Tuan Sing Holdings reported a 52% year-on-year decline in Q3 net profit to $5.8 million due to lower revenue from redevelopment property sales. Group revenue fell 35% to $54.2 million, while 9M13 net profit declined 12% to $26.7 million. The company attributed the decline to the sale of development properties, but noted that ongoing projects such as Sennett Residences and new acquisitions will contribute to future growth.

site_title: Quotation of taxable book-entry Singapore Government Bonds (Oct 31, 2013)
summary: Singapore Government Bonds quotation for taxable book-entry closed on October 31, 2013. No further information is provided.

site_title: Clifford Capital prices maiden bond issue
summary: Clifford Capital priced its maiden US$300 million five-year notes, the first-ever US dollar bond issue guaranteed by the Singapore government. The notes achieved tight pricing and were sought after by global investors. This debut in the international USD bond markets was strongly supported by the global investor community, according to HSBC head of Debt Capital Markets, Jason Khoo.

site_title: SMRT's Q2 profit dives 57% to $14m
summary: SMRT Corp's Q2 net profit plunged 56.8% to $14.4 million due to higher staff and depreciation costs, despite a 5.3% rise in revenue to $296.3 million. The company's fare business remains challenging, with train operating profit falling 50.7% to $20 million. SMRT is discussing a transition to a sustainable model for its train and bus business, and has seen growth in its non-fare business.

site_title: Homebuyers spoilt for choice in Iskandar
summary: Iskandar Malaysia, a Malaysian economic zone, is experiencing a surge in real estate development amid rising demand and stiff competition. Builders, including local developers and larger companies from Klang Valley, are unveiling new launches, with thousands of units scheduled for completion over the next two to three years. The rivalry has led to a diverse range of projects, including waterfront developments, integrated townships, and wellness-themed complexes. State-owned UEM Sunrise and Iskandar Waterfront Holdings are expected to play a major role in the zone's development, with UEM Sunrise master-developing Nusajaya and Iskandar Waterfront Holdings developing Flagship A.

site_title: Fragrance Group Q3 profit dips 3.7%
summary: Fragrance Group, a property developer and hotel operator, reported a 3.7% dip in Q3 profit to $22.8 million, despite higher gross profits and a 6.5% year-on-year increase in turnover. The company attributed the decline to increased costs and taxes. Gross profit rose 14.3% to $57.2 million, driven by higher contributions from its property and hotel businesses. The board did not recommend a dividend for the quarter. Despite the dip, the company expects to remain profitable in 2013.

site_title: A product that is complex for many
summary: Investors are flocking to alternative mutual funds, which use complex strategies to protect against market declines and interest rate movements. However, financial advisers warn of the risks, citing difficulty in distinguishing skilled money managers from lucky ones. Many of these funds are expensive, with average fees of 1.77% of assets, and some charge up to 2% of assets and 20% of profits. Despite concerns, the industry continues to grow, with 55 new alternative funds introduced this year, and large hedge fund players expanding into mass-market offerings.

site_title: Singapore firm turns to High Court for protection against PNG govt
summary: A Singapore-based non-profit, PNG Sustainable Development Program Ltd, has sued the Papua New Guinea government in the High Court, seeking to nullify the purported sacking of its board, including prominent director Lim How Teck, and to prevent the wrongful appropriation of US$1.4 billion in assets. The PNG government has passed legislation allowing it to restructure the company and expropriate its assets, including a 63.4% stake in the Ok Tedi mine. The company claims the legislation is "unlawful" and violates international law, and is seeking declarations and an order to stop the government from taking action on its assets.

site_title: Asiasons eyes $25m convertible loan facility from directors
summary: Asiasons Capital, a struggling investment firm, plans to take a $25 million convertible loan facility from two key directors, Ng Teck Wah and Jared Lim Chih Li, as a source of standby capital. The four-year facility will incur 6% annual interest and may be repaid in shares at a 58% premium to the current stock price. The deal needs approval from independent shareholders due to its interested-party nature. Asiasons will use the facility for investments and working capital, with $20 million set aside for investments and $5 million for working capital.

site_title: Ezra wins US$110m worth of new projects
summary: Ezra Holdings' subsea services and offshore support divisions secured US$110 million worth of new projects in the Gulf of Mexico and Asia-Pacific regions. Emas AMC won a SURF-type offshore installation project and pipeline repair works, while Emas Marine secured charters for anchor handling and supply vessels. The projects are scheduled to begin before year-end and will be managed from Houston and Singapore offices. Ezra has an order book of over US$2 billion and expects revenue from outside South-east Asia to remain strong.

site_title: CapitaMalls Asia Q3 profit up 4%
summary: CapitaMalls Asia reported a 4% increase in Q3 net profit to $64.8 million, driven by a 38.6% rise in associate results. Revenue fell 10.1% to $91.8 million, mainly due to lower management fees in China. Despite this, the company's key markets of Singapore, China, and Malaysia continued to record growth, with net property income and tenants' sales rising in the first nine months. The company expects to open two malls in Singapore in the fourth quarter, despite delays in other projects.

site_title: NOL Q3 profit plunges 60% to US$20m
summary: NOL reported a 60% decline in Q3 net profit to US$20m, down from US$50m last year, due to lower freight rates and volume. Revenue declined 10% to US$2.06 billion. APL's revenue slid 13% to US$1.7 billion, with a 5% decrease in total volume. Despite weak demand conditions, NOL aims to trim capacity and reconfigure services to improve cost structure and deliver better performance in 2013.

site_title: Asians face retirement savings shortfall: survey
summary: Asians face significant retirement savings shortfalls, with Singaporeans estimating a 7-year shortfall of approximately $250,000. The Manulife Investor Sentiment Index found that 40% of assets are invested in cash, and many respondents underestimate their retirement needs. In Singapore, 69% of respondents expect to work part-time or full-time in retirement, and only 11% feel comfortable relying on their children for financial assistance. Investor sentiment in Asia fell sharply in the third quarter, with the main concerns being market volatility and government measures to cool property prices.

site_title: Blazes at cruise liners spur calls for scrutiny
summary: Cruise ships continue to grow in size, but safety experts and lawmakers are raising concerns about the potential risks for passengers and crew. Recent incidents, including a fire on the Carnival Triumph and a capsized ship, Costa Concordia, have highlighted fatal lapses in safety and emergency procedures. Operators argue that larger ships have more fire safety equipment, but experts say that bigger ships pose more significant challenges in emergency situations. Senator John Rockefeller has introduced legislation to strengthen federal oversight of cruise lines' safety procedures and consumer protections, amid calls for greater accountability.

site_title: Soilbuild posts 13% rise in Q3 earnings
summary: Soilbuild Construction Group reported a 13% year-on-year increase in Q3 net profit to $6.32 million, driven by healthy progress in its construction projects. The company's July-September turnover rose 44% to $84.54 million, with new projects including a mixed-used development and an HDB project. This marks the ninth consecutive quarter of growth for the group.

site_title: DP World container volume up 2%
summary: DP World reported a 2% rise in consolidated container volumes to 6.7 million TEU in the third quarter, on a like-for-like basis. The company cited improved performance from its Asia Pacific and UAE terminals, with the UAE accounting for 3.6 million TEU. Despite a challenging first half, DP World's CEO Mohammed Sharaf expressed optimism, stating the company remains on track to achieve gross like-for-like volumes in line with 2012, while focusing on driving profitability through higher margin throughput and improving efficiencies.

site_title: Grand Banks sets profit course to exit SGX watch-list
summary: Grand Banks Yachts, a Singapore-based luxury yacht manufacturer, is on track to exit the Singapore Exchange's watch-list after making significant progress in meeting the criteria. The company has increased its market capitalisation to $38 million through a recent rights issue and reported a net profit of $579,000 in its first quarter. With a strong order book and improving performance, Grand Banks is hopeful of being delisted by the end of the year, pending an extension of the deadline.

site_title: Great Eastern Q3 gain down by half
summary: Great Eastern Holdings reported a 54% decline in third-quarter net profit to $282.8 million, despite a 26% increase in core operating profit to $138.6 million. Excluding a one-time gain from the sale of F&N and APB, the insurer would have seen a 43% increase in net profit. The company's insurance business saw improved sales, particularly in bancassurance products in Singapore, but faces uncertainty from new financial advisory rules and global economic conditions.

site_title: Korean Air counter falls over affiliate funding
summary: Korean Air Lines dropped 9.9% in Seoul trading due to concerns that the company may provide further funding to its affiliate Hanjin Shipping, which is facing a liquidity shortage. Korean Air said it would provide 150 billion won (S$175.1 million) to ease the shortage, despite posting a loss for the first nine months due to weak travel demand on its Japan services. Analysts warn that the airline industry isn't doing well, and Korean Air has significant debt coming due next year.

site_title: SingPost Q2 net up 8.5% at $35.7m
summary: SingPost reported an 8.5% increase in Q2 profit to $35.7 million, driven by strong growth in e-commerce and logistics segments. Revenue surged 32.6% to $204 million, with mail business growing 13.4% and logistics revenue increasing 79.1%. The company aims to expand e-commerce and digital services, while focusing on cost management and investing $100 million in postal infrastructure over the next three years.

site_title: S'pore firms unveil big overseas investments
summary: Singapore-based companies Pontiac Land Group and GIC Real Estate have announced significant overseas property investments. Pontiac is partnering with Goldman Sachs and Hines to develop a luxury condominium in New York City, with a development cost of over US$1.3 billion, while GIC Real Estate is acquiring a 47-storey office tower in Jakarta, Indonesia, for US$350 million. Both investments reflect a step towards diversifying Singapore's property market and are seen as a strategic move to escape local cooling measures.

site_title: Singapore consumers less pessimistic in Q3: Nielsen survey
summary: Singapore consumers reported a slight increase in confidence levels in Q3, with a score of 98 points, similar to the same period last year. Despite this, the country's consumer confidence index remains below the 100-point baseline, indicating a level of pessimism. Job prospects and personal finances improved, with 61% of Singaporeans rating their job prospects as good or excellent and 54% viewing their personal finances positively. Investment sentiment also increased globally, with 57% of markets reporting an increase in investment intentions.

site_title: IndoAgri earnings continue to slide
summary: IndoAgri, a subsidiary of IndoFood, reported a 52% decline in earnings for the third quarter due to lower selling prices and higher production costs. Net profit fell to 122.9 billion rupiah, with revenue down 13% to 3.08 trillion rupiah. The decline was attributed to weaker palm and rubber prices, as well as lower sales volume in edible oils and fats. Gross profit declined by 22% due to rising wages and production costs, while a foreign exchange loss and investment losses further eroded the bottom line.

site_title: Firms do better when CFOs work closely with supply chain chiefs: poll
summary: A global study by EY found that companies with CFOs who have a strong "business partnering" relationship with supply chain leaders report better results than those with a traditional finance model. Almost half of these companies experienced Ebitda growth of over 5% in the past year, compared to 22% of those with a traditional relationship. The study, which surveyed 423 CFOs and heads of supply chain, found that collaboration between the two is growing, with 70% of CFOs and 63% of supply chain leaders reporting a more collaborative relationship over the past three years.

site_title: Tharman on keeping joblessness down, pay up
summary: Deputy Prime Minister Tharman Shanmugaratnam outlined three strategies to maintain low unemployment and high income in Singapore: a vibrant economy, quality growth, and an inclusive society. These strategies must be executed together, with a focus on promoting jobs through skills upgrading to ensure low unemployment. Tharman emphasized the need to balance higher productivity with job creation, as Singapore strives for quality growth.

site_title: Food and spices become her art
summary: Korean artist Haegue Yang's exhibition at the Singapore Tyler Print Institute features "spice moons," two-dimensional art pieces created from paper and spices. Yang, who represented South Korea at the Venice Biennale in 2009, uses everyday objects like food and spices to explore themes of migration, diaspora, and assimilation. Her works include spice-scented paper, spice packaging fonts, and even instant noodles, showcasing her sense of humor and intimate connection with the audience. The exhibition runs until November 23, with free admission.

site_title: Hacker threatens to take down S'pore infrastructure
summary: A hacker claiming to be part of the Anonymous group has threatened to take down Singapore's key infrastructure in protest of the government's new licensing rules for websites. The hacker, wearing a Guy Fawkes mask, warned the government to reconsider the regulations or face financial loss through cyber intrusion. The threat was made in a YouTube video posted on Tuesday, referencing a previous hack by a "comrade" known as "The Messiah". The IDA and police are investigating the matter, despite the video being taken down from YouTube.

site_title: Boeing in talks on orders worth US$87b for 777X
summary: Boeing is in talks with four airlines, including Emirates, Qatar Airways, Etihad Airways, and Cathay Pacific, to place orders for its redesigned 777X jetliner valued at up to $87 billion. The 255 planes under discussion could include 100-150 for Emirates, 50 for Qatar, and 30 for Etihad. An order for the 777X would be a boost for Boeing ahead of the jet's commercial debut, potentially keeping Airbus at bay in the market for the biggest twin-engine jets.

site_title: Norway central bank okay with housing deflation
summary: Norway's central bank governor Oeystein Olsen stated that the economy can withstand house price deflation and will avoid policies that drive up the property market. The housing market is showing signs of a slowdown, with house price growth slowing to 2.6% in September, its smallest increase since June 2009. The central bank has introduced measures to cool the market, but Olsen is prepared to tolerate sustained house price declines due to financial imbalances. He believes the economy can withstand a moderate downward reaction in housing prices without entering a recession.

site_title: Sin Heng Q1 net profit up 15.8% at $3.8m
summary: Sin Heng Heavy Machinery reported a net profit of $3.8 million for its first quarter, up 15.8% from the same period last year, driven by a 10.1% increase in revenue. The company attributed the higher profit to its trading segment, which saw an 85% jump in gross profit, while equipment rental gross profit declined. Sin Heng has reduced its net debt from $9 million to almost $10 million and has a cash position of $10 million, with a "buy" call from Phillip Securities Research.

site_title: Muddy Waters: Game over for Olam if Temasek pulls out
summary: Muddy Waters, a short-selling research firm, warns that if Temasek pulls out of its investment in Olam International, the agri-commodities trader will likely face financial difficulties, potentially leading to "game over" for the company. Olam has been struggling with negative free cash flows and high debt levels, despite efforts to cut costs and become cash flow positive by 2014. Temasek's support for Olam has been seen as a lifeline, but Muddy Waters believes that Temasek's decision to invest in the company was likely driven by systemic issues in Singapore rather than a genuine investment case.

site_title: RTO: Albedo gets waiver on pro forma financial data
summary: Albedo, a Catalist-listed company, has received a waiver from the Singapore Exchange to not disclose pro forma financial data for its existing business and target company, Reflections Oasis. This is due to the operations and financial position of the existing group not being relevant to the listed group. Albedo is focusing on its new business as a major property developer in Iskandar Malaysia after agreeing to a $774.14 million reverse takeover deal. The company will disclose pro forma financial information for the post-completion group structure instead.

site_title: Number of LCC seats in Asia jumps 28.7% in H1
summary: Asia saw a 28.7% increase in low-cost carrier (LCC) seats in the first half of 2013, driven mainly by budget carriers in Indonesia, India, Thailand, and Malaysia. The number of LCC seats in Asia reached 129.3 million, with Indonesia having the highest growth in capacity, up 44% compared to 1H 2012. This growth contrasts with mature markets in Europe and the Americas, which saw flat or marginal increases in LCC capacity.

site_title: Why big money is chasing Silicon Valley tech startups
summary: Big money is pouring into Silicon Valley tech startups, with companies like Pinterest, Fab, and Alibaba Group Holding receiving massive investments despite lacking revenue. Pinterest's $225 million funding round valued the company at $3.8 billion, while Fab's $1 billion valuation and Alibaba's $600 million investment in ShopRunner are also eye-catching. This trend may indicate an investment bubble, with enthusiasm outpacing reality in the tech industry. Investors like Fidelity and Rizvi Traverse Management are taking a riskier approach, focusing on growth and expansion rather than immediate returns.

site_title: JAL's net profit in H1 slips 17.8% to US$833m
summary: Japan Airlines (JAL) reported a 17.8% drop in net profit to US$833 million for the first half of 2013, mainly due to the strong yen and rising fuel costs. Despite this, the company remains optimistic about the full year, citing strong demand for flights to South-east Asia and cost-cutting efforts. JAL's operating profit decreased 14.6% to 95.84 billion, but sales edged up 4.0% to 659.30 billion.

images.alt_text: Tough times: In a half that saw the grounding of its Dreamliners, JAL made 81.94b yen, with an operating profit that was down 14.6% at 95.84b. - PHOTO: BLOOMBERG

site_title: Asia-Pacific air freight traffic down 3.1% in Sept
summary: Asia-Pacific air freight carriers saw a 3.1% year-on-year decline in September, despite global traffic edging up 0.5%. Strong growth from Middle Eastern and Latin American carriers offset the decline, with Middle Eastern carriers reporting a 9.9% increase and Latin American airlines seeing a 3.9% expansion. The global cargo market is stabilizing, with overall air cargo volumes reaching a 25-month high. Industry experts expect the cargo market to lag behind passenger markets, with a 0.9% expected growth for the year.

images.alt_text: Mr Tyler added: "But the persistent cargo weakness when compared to the strength of passenger markets is a signal for the industry to work at improving its value proposition." - PHOTO: BLOOMBERG

site_title: Higher wages, costs and consumer prices ahead
summary: Singapore's Monetary Authority (MAS) expects inflation to rise in the next few quarters before easing towards the end of 2014. Strong wage growth, driven by a tight labour market, is expected to push business costs and consumer prices higher. The MAS forecasts core inflation to rise to 2.5% in Q2 2014 and headline inflation to reach 3.5% in Q2 2014, before easing to below 2% in Q4 2014. This is driven by increasing costs and consumer prices, particularly in the services sector, where inflation is expected to rise to around 3% in H2 2013 and the whole of 2014.

site_title: S'pore well-placed to capitalise on demands of an affluent Asia
summary: Singapore is well-positioned to capitalize on the growing demand for high-end consumer goods and modern services in affluent Asia. The country's external growth drivers are likely to shift towards emerging Asia as global rebalancing continues. Singapore's intra-Asian trade growth is expected to rise, driven by demand from China and major Asean economies, making it a key services hub in the region. Despite increased competition in intermediate goods, Singapore can exploit niche opportunities in high-end consumer goods and modern services.

site_title: Atomic laughs
summary: Singaporean playwright and director Huzir Sulaiman's play "Atomic Jaya" satirizes the idea of Malaysia building a nuclear bomb, with a focus on slapstick humor and archetypes. The play follows a geeky physicist, Mary Yuen, as she's recruited to build a bomb by a vainglorious general, despite her moral and ethical concerns. With talented performances by Karen Tan and Claire Wong, the play pokes fun at Malaysian stereotypes while showcasing sophisticated direction and production design. "Atomic Jaya" runs at the School of the Arts' Drama Centre until its final show.

site_title: Unveiling the familiar in a strange place
summary: A South Korean novel, "Your Republic Is Calling You" by Kim Young-ha, explores the North and South Korean conflict through the story of a seemingly ordinary man who is secretly a North Korean spy. The novel, originally published in 2006, follows the spy's life in South Korea and his return to North Korea after receiving a coded email. The story offers a humanized perspective on the conflict, delving into the complexities of life on both sides of the divide.

site_title: Cross-cultural collaborations
summary: Malaysian dancer Wong Jyh Shyong, artistic director of the Damansara Performing Arts Centre, will collaborate with Korean choreographer Choi Myung Hyun and Singaporean dancer Liz Fong on an Asian Festivals Exchange event. Wong and Choi explored common themes of time and space in their dance styles, while Fong and Japanese dancer Yuriko Suzuki found a rich pool of possibilities in their exchanged ideas. The event aims to showcase cross-cultural collaborations and promote artistic understanding through dance.

site_title: Who's afraid of Catherine Breillat?
summary: French writer and filmmaker Catherine Breillat, known for her unflinching examinations of human sexuality, will appear at the Singapore Writers Festival. At 16, she published her first novel, "L'Homme facile," which was banned in France due to its explicit content. Breillat's works often explore complex female sexuality, drawing inspiration from her own rebellious adolescence and readings of influential authors. Her upcoming films, "Bluebeard" and "Sleeping Beauty," will be screened at the festival, showcasing her unique perspective on fairy tales and female empowerment.

site_title: At a glance
summary: Singapore's NTT DC Reit's public offer was 9.8 times oversubscribed. US stocks opened lower amid President Trump's new tariff on Canada. Creative Technology warned of lower-than-target H2 revenue and a similar operating loss to H1. London's Heathrow is considering higher fees for its £10 billion upgrade. Indonesia detained a Trafigura employee in a graft case. OCBC appointed Tan Teck Long as its incoming CEO, replacing a DBS veteran. MAS and PBOC plan to deepen cooperation in green and transition finance, and Singapore stocks rallied for a 5-day streak ahead of GDP data.

site_title: GST - A laudable step taken by Najib
summary: Malaysia has opted for a 6% goods and services tax (GST) effective April 2015, replacing sales and service taxes. The new tax system will exempt basic necessities like rice and cooking oil, and also excludes government services. To ease the transition, those earning RM4,000 or less per month will no longer pay income tax. Corporate and small enterprise tax rates will be reduced from 2016. The system will add complexity, but Prime Minister Najib Razak's administration aims to balance the country's finances.

site_title: Learning with the best
summary: The Rolex Master and Protege Initiative held its sixth cycle in Venice, matching veterans in the international arts world with upcoming talents. The weekend featured performances by artists including Gilberto Gil, Lin Hwai-min, and William Kentridge. The event aimed to keep the fire of creativity going, providing a platform for veterans to mentor and inspire young artists. The initiative, a biennial program, supports the arts and fosters collaboration between established and emerging artists.

site_title: Brokers raise shields with Sky One falling
summary: Sky One Holdings, a Singapore logistics provider, collapsed in value by as much as 91% on Monday due to a reverse takeover by a coal-mining business. Trading in the stock is currently restricted at several brokers, including AmFraser and OCBC Securities, with restrictions on online trading, short-selling, and Internet trading. The Singapore Exchange (SGX) has not imposed trading curbs, despite querying the company, sparking questions about its risk management and communication. The incident has raised concerns about the volatility of penny stocks and the need for clearer guidelines.

site_title: Second Chance posts record profits
summary: Second Chance Properties (SCP) reported a record net profit of $57 million for the year ended August 31, 2013, driven by a $43 million gain on the revaluation of its properties. Revenue declined to $54 million from $64.6 million in the previous year due to a change in financial year end. The company expects to remain profitable for FY2014, with its apparel business performing well and gold business remaining profitable. SCP proposed a second and final dividend of 1.7 cents per share, making it 3.4 cents for the year.

site_title: Ryanair changes image as demand weakens
summary: Ryanair, Europe's largest and most profitable budget airline, is making changes to address criticism and weak demand due to Europe's economic slump. The airline will reduce fees for carry-on bags and online check-in, and will also reduce in-flight announcements and "quiet flights" before 8 am. Ryanair will also revamp its website and introduce a free smartphone app. CEO Michael O'Leary acknowledges the need for a subtler tone and is exploring ways to appeal to higher-paying business travelers, such as reserved seating and priority boarding.

site_title: UK plans to launch Islamic sovereign bond
summary: The UK plans to launch its first Syariah-compliant sovereign bond, worth £200 million, next year, marking the first time a non-Islamic country has issued such a bond. The move is part of the UK's efforts to establish London as a major hub for Islamic finance, with the city already home to more Syariah-compliant banks and law firms than anywhere else outside the Islamic world. The launch is expected to contribute to the growing value of Syariah-compliant assets, which are expected to reach $6.5 trillion by 2020.

site_title: Singapore still No. 1 in World Bank's business-friendy list
summary: Singapore has maintained its position as the most business-friendly country for the eighth consecutive year, according to the World Bank's annual ranking. The country's trading platform, TradeNet, was cited as an example of global good practice. Singapore ranked high in trading across borders and protecting investors, but performed poorly in registering property, ranking 28th. Despite this, the government has introduced online procedures and improved credit information systems to facilitate business. Other countries in the region, such as the Philippines and Malaysia, have also shown improvement in business regulations.

site_title: Rex Int'l forms JV for oil production technology
summary: Rex International is forming a joint venture with Swiss company Ogsonic to provide a proprietary oil production technology using ultrasound to clean clogged wells, increasing oil production by 30-380%. Rex will hold 66.7% of the JV, Rexonic, and plans a private share placement to finance the venture and other opportunities, raising up to $52.85 million. The technology has the potential to increase onshore and offshore oil production, complementing Rex's core competence in oil exploration.

site_title: A balloon ride to the stratosphere in great comfort
summary: A new space tourism company, World View, plans to offer balloon rides to the stratosphere as early as 2015, priced at US$75,000, including champagne. Led by the same team behind Inspiration Mars, a 2018 Mars flyby mission, the company aims to provide a comfortable high-altitude experience. This marks a new frontier in space tourism, focusing on luxury and comfort rather than traditional rocket-based travel.

site_title: AMR-US Airways merger case goes to mediator
summary: American Airlines, US Airways Group, and the US Justice Department agreed to use a mediator to resolve the government's lawsuit blocking the proposed airline merger. The Justice Department sued in August, claiming the merger would reduce competition and lead to higher prices. A status conference is set for today, and a trial is scheduled for November 25, 2013. If the US is successful, AMR would have to restart its reorganization process, potentially causing disruption to stakeholders.

site_title: Sky One, Tritech shares crash
summary: Shares in Sky One and Tritech Group plummeted, sparking fears of an SGX designation as "designated securities." This led to spillover selling pressure on the penny segment. The collapse was attributed to Nosedive's triggers. The SGX may designate the stocks due to their significant losses, similar to three other cases recently.

site_title: Taking time-outs keep Matchbox Twenty on top
summary: Matchbox Twenty frontman Rob Thomas has enjoyed a successful solo career, releasing two platinum-selling albums, but also values his time with the band, stating it's "home" for him. The band, formed in 1995, went on hiatus in 2004 but reunited in 2007 to record their fourth studio album, North, which debuted at number one in the US and Australia. The band is currently on tour, playing sold-out shows in North America and Australia, and will perform in Singapore next month. Thomas credits the time apart from the band for bringing new ideas and energy to their reunion.

site_title: Macquarie eyes a slice of Aussie banks' home mortgage pie
summary: Macquarie Group Ltd, Australia's largest investment bank, is rapidly expanding into the country's lucrative home mortgage market, threatening the dominance of the top four lenders. The bank aims to capitalize on the high returns, with an estimated profit of A$75,000 over the lifetime of an average-sized 25-year home loan. Macquarie's move is seen as a smart diversification into less risky areas, as the bank deploys considerable cash balances to fund home loans. This could disrupt the market, offering borrowers a competitive alternative to the Big Four.

site_title: Redas president position up in the air
summary: Redas president Chia Boon Kuah's position is uncertain as he leaves Far East Organization next year. Chia, who is currently president, may not automatically become the new president due to Redas' election process, where members elect office holders from among themselves. The possibility exists for Chia to be re-elected, as he could be nominated as a representative from Guocoland, one of Redas' management committee members, and then elected by the committee. This is not unprecedented, as a former Redas president resigned during his term in 1997.

site_title: Dubai property sukuk rally on Expo hopes
summary: Dubai is optimistic about hosting the 2020 World Expo, with local developers Emaar Properties and Nakheel experiencing record-low yields for their Islamic bonds. A winning bid could boost the economy by 0.5 percentage points per year, with 26 billion dirhams of infrastructure expected. The selection could also benefit real estate, hospitality, and construction sectors, potentially leading to a boom in economic growth.

site_title: Enliven your home with animal chic
summary: Taxidermy is experiencing a resurgence in home decor, particularly in the US, with many retailers offering artistically interpreted mounts of animals such as rhinos, giraffes, and elephants made from papier mache, resin, ceramic, and wood. The trend, which originated in Brooklyn, has been around for centuries and is also seen in Paris' famous Maison Deyrolle, where taxidermy is used to create intricate and handcrafted displays. The trend is expected to continue, with many homeowners incorporating animal prints and textiles into their design, but caution is advised to avoid over-accessorizing with too many animal-themed items.

site_title: Credit Suisse concerned about rise in industrial property
summary: Credit Suisse expresses concern over the industrial property segment due to a 2.8% price gain in Q3, following a 0.6% fall in Q2. Industrial rents rose 4.4% after a 0.1% decline in Q2, while vacancy rates remained flat at 21.7%. The report warns of potential further measures to curb a bubble and notes that private-sector office demand was a positive surprise, while suburban malls are favored for their resilience.

site_title: Three-Minute Digest
summary: Singapore's wage growth continues to outpace the historical average, putting pressure on businesses to manage increasing costs. The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) notes that the country is more exposed to advanced economies than emerging Asia. Despite this, Singapore remains the most business-friendly country for the eighth consecutive year. Economies like DBS and UOB are expected to show less stellar Q3 earnings, while OCBC's performance will be boosted by accounting gains. Meanwhile, India's central bank raised interest rates to combat inflation, and the IMF expressed caution on Japan's economic prospects.

site_title: Norwegian Cruise Line Q3 earnings up 33%
summary: Norwegian Cruise Line Holdings reported a 33% year-on-year increase in Q3 earnings to $170.9 million, driven by improved ticket pricing and onboard spend. EPS rose to $0.84, from $0.72 last year. Despite a net loss of $105.2 million in the first six months, the company expects its 2014 EPS to be $2.22, down from $2.33. The cruise line will introduce new ships, including Norwegian Getaway and Norwegian Escape, in 2014 and 2017, respectively.

site_title: Far East buys two Aussie properties for A$277m
summary: Far East Organization has signed conditional contracts to buy two Australian properties for A$277 million ($328 million). The purchases include a Sydney mixed-use development, Clocktower Square, and a Perth shopping centre, Harbour Town Centre. The deals are part of the group's strategy to expand its property investment portfolio beyond Singapore and Malaysia, with the acquisitions expected to be completed in November and December, respectively.

site_title: No subsidies for renewable energy use
summary: Singapore will not subsidize renewable energy options, even as it prepares to incorporate solar energy into its power system. Minister S Iswaran announced a public consultation on a regulatory framework for intermittent generation sources, increasing the cap on solar energy from 350 MW to 600 MW. The move aims to ensure system stability and back up intermittent sources. Iswaran emphasized that renewables should be integrated on a fully costed basis to avoid wasteful over-consumption and distorted energy use decisions.

site_title: Super troupers from Down Under
summary: John Tyrrell, founder of ABBA tribute band Bjorn Again, reflects on the band's 25-year history. Since its inception in 1988, Bjorn Again has performed over 7,000 live shows in 100+ countries, including a memorable appearance on a Swedish TV show where Bjorn Ulvaeus endorsed the band. Despite the original ABBA's "no" to reuniting, Bjorn Again has become a credible tribute band, earning awards and praise from fans and industry professionals. The band continues to tour, with upcoming performances in Singapore.

site_title: Yanlord buys site on Nanjing Eco-Island
summary: Chinese developer Yanlord Land Group has acquired a 38.6-hectare site on the Nanjing Eco-Island for 2.88 billion yuan, with plans to develop a mixed-use project. The site will feature residential, commercial, and R&D space, including a kindergarten. Yanlord is a co-investor in the joint venture, along with other companies. The acquisition marks a new chapter in Yanlord's 20-year history, according to chairman Zhong Sheng Jian.

site_title: Raffles Medical Q3 net up 10.3% at $13.87m
summary: Raffles Medical Group reported a 10.3% increase in its third-quarter net profit to $13.87 million, driven by a higher patient load and improved operating efficiencies. Revenue rose 8% to $85.05 million, with hospital services and healthcare services divisions recording higher revenues. Staff costs increased 8.3% to $42.2 million, but operating profit rose 11.2% to $16.8 million. The group expects strong performance to continue, with plans to open new medical centres in suburban areas. Its cash position stands at $146.1 million.

site_title: Company Briefs
summary: Blumont Group terminated its share deal with Prospect Resources due to the issuer's failure to meet conditions by the October 30 deadline. Meanwhile, MAPLETREE Greater China Commercial Trust reported a 10.4% higher DPU of 3.183 cents, exceeding forecasts. NTT DC Reit's Singapore public offer received 9.8 times oversubscription.

site_title: Company Briefs
summary: ST Aerospace secured a three-year line maintenance contract for Jetstar Asia's Airbus A320 fleet. Boustead Singapore won a design-build-and-lease contract for a 24,800 sqm maintenance facility at Tukang Innovation Park. King Wan Corp secured $26m of new M&E contracts, while TEE Int'l signed a $142m engineering package for the Marina South Mixed Development Project.

site_title: Weakness in PMET job market for locals seen to be dissipating
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) reported that recent government curbs on foreign labor inflows may boost job opportunities for tertiary-educated locals, particularly at the entry level. The new Fair Consideration Framework aims to ensure that Singaporean professionals are fairly considered for jobs. Despite a constrained job market, MAS noted that the unemployment rate of tertiary-educated residents has trended up since 2012, but the number of these workers has risen to equal that of non-tertiary educated ones for the first time. This shift reflects the replacement of older residents with more qualified entrants.

site_title: SGX to launch Asian forex futures next month
summary: SGX to launch Asian forex futures on Nov 11, introducing six currency pairs, including AUD/USD and USD/SGD. The move is in line with global G-20 regulatory reforms, promoting transparency and better serving investment and risk-management needs in the Asian time zone. The exchange plans to introduce new Asean equity index futures and dynamic circuit breakers in the next few quarters.

site_title: Forterra Trust sinks into the red in Q3
summary: Forterra Trust reported a net loss of $2.3 million in Q3, down from a $8.8 million profit a year ago. The loss per unit was 0.9 cents, against 3.5 cents previously. Gross revenue fell 25% to $18.3 million due to divestment and retail tenant moves. Net property income declined 24% to $11.6 million. Forterra attributes losses to underdeveloped assets and a smaller forex gain. Despite this, the trust remains optimistic about the newly launched Shanghai free trade zone, which it believes will boost demand for office and retail properties.

site_title: Abu Dhabi fund eyes US, Europe investments
summary: Mubadala Real Estate & Infrastructure, a unit of Abu Dhabi's investment fund, plans to shift its focus from developing real estate to investing in property in the US, Europe, and emerging markets. The company, which is the single largest shareholder in Aldar Properties, aims to deploy capital internationally and has no immediate plans to sell its stake in the developer. A new strategy will be implemented by the end of the year or early next year, outlining the amount of capital to be invested, with strong cities in the US and Europe being targeted.

site_title: More solar means more investment: SP
summary: Singapore Power (SP) will need to make a significant investment in additional infrastructure to handle a two-way power flow in the electricity grid as solar energy supply increases. The current cap on intermittent generation sources is set to rise from 600 MW to 1,000 MW, representing 10% of peak electricity demand. Existing infrastructure can handle the current increase, but further upgrades will be needed to ensure power system stability. Investment details are not disclosed, but liberalization of the power market has attracted $78 billion in capital inflows over the past five years.

site_title: Mostly disappointing superhero sequel
summary: Thor: The Dark World, the sequel to the 2011 film Thor, is a disappointing follow-up that lacks the confidence and levity of its predecessor. The movie follows Thor as he teams up with his adoptive brother Loki to stop an evil force known as the Aether and destroy Asgard. Despite some nice individual moments, the film is formulaic, muddled, and weighed down by the need to provide extended narrative and back story to the villain. The movie's effects-led approach and lack of character development make it feel uninspired, with Thor's star shining slightly out of alignment.

site_title: Power futures trading will be done in a half-hour window
summary: Singapore plans to launch a daily half-hour window for trading electricity futures, based on spot electricity prices provided by the Energy Market Company. The market will be operated by the Singapore Exchange and is expected to be finalized later this week. The initial market trial will involve six market makers, including big energy companies, and is set to begin in early 2014, with a target implementation date of the second half of 2014. The trial will allow market makers to decide whether to stay with the scheme and has been welcomed by industry officials.

site_title: What efficient markets are all about
summary: Nobel laureate Eugene Fama explains his views on the efficient markets theory, which states that prices reflect all available information. Fama's work, along with Lars Peter Hansen and Robert J. Shiller, won the 2013 Nobel Prize in economics. Fama's research has shown that while markets can be unpredictable in the short term, there are factors such as the dividend-stock price ratio and the spread of the market return over the Treasury bill rate that can help predict longer-term stock prices. Fama disagrees with Shiller's views on the role of investor psychology and emotion in financial markets, and he believes that the variation in expected returns is rational. He also advocates for smaller government and less regulation, and has expressed skepticism about the effectiveness of government spending in counteracting recessions.

site_title: Less stellar Q3 seen for DBS, UOB
summary: Singapore's DBS Group Holdings and United Overseas Bank (UOB) are expected to report slower Q3 earnings due to slower loan growth, softer capital markets, and weak wealth management fees. Analysts predict net profits of $839 million, $648 million, and $703 million for DBS, UOB, and OCBC, respectively. Loan growth is expected to slow from a high base in the first half of the year, with DBS and OCBC projected to grow 17.2% and 14% year-on-year, respectively. The banks' non-interest income is also expected to be impacted, with DBS's non-interest income falling 12% and UOB's non-interest income boosted by one-off gains from the sale of its stake in Pan Pacific Hotels.

site_title: Advanced economies have bigger impact on S'pore
summary: Singapore's economy is expected to grow 2.5-3.5% in 2013, influenced by the relative growth performance of developed and emerging market economies. Emerging Asia's slowdown, particularly in China, is unlikely to negate the positive effects of a recovery in developed countries, such as the US, eurozone, and Japan. Singapore's exposure to developed economies is higher, with 24% of GDP tied to the G3, compared to 14% to emerging Asia. A stronger G3 recovery is expected to boost Singapore's exports, particularly in the IT industry.

site_title: Three-Minute Digest
summary: The jobless rate in Singapore fell to 1.8% in September, the lowest since December 2012, as layoffs subsided in Q3. Businesses are investing and expanding while consumers are cutting back on borrowing. In other news, CapitaLand's Q3 profit fell 8.7%, and China's top 4 banks posted a rise in non-performing loans. The US criticized China and Germany for their trade surpluses, while the UK's plan to issue an Islamic bond received mixed reactions.

site_title: HK home prices to fall 30% by end-2015: Barclays
summary: Barclays predicts Hong Kong home prices will fall at least 30% by the end of 2015 due to stagnant income growth and increased supply. Analysts attribute the downward spiral to developers and homeowners adjusting expectations, assigning a "negative" rating to the Hong Kong property sector. This forecast exceeds previous predictions and implies the biggest price drop since 1998, reversing the nearly doubling of home prices since 2009.

site_title: Healthway Q3 net jumps to $10.1m
summary: Healthway Medical Corporation, Singapore's largest private medical centres and clinics, reported a third-quarter net profit of $10.1 million, up from $1.07 million last year. The increase was mainly due to a gain of $22.4 million from the disposal of available-for-sale financial assets. This is a significant improvement from the previous year, when the company's "other operating income" was $3 million.

site_title: Noble presses Yanzhou to raise Yancoal offer
summary: China's Yanzhou Coal Mining Co is under pressure to raise its US$191 million offer to take its Australian Yancoal unit private from Singapore's Noble Group, a key Yancoal shareholder. Noble has proposed a higher offer, and Yanzhou must decide whether to accept or increase the initial A$0.91 per share price to proceed with the deal.

site_title: Watchable and heartwarming
summary: Japanese director Hirokazu Kore-eda's film "Like Father Like Son" tells the story of two families who discover that their children were switched at birth. The film, a slow-burning tearjerker, explores the contrasting parenting styles of Ryota and Yudai as they navigate their relationships with their sons. The film's heartwarming and watchable, thanks to the charm of its child actors, particularly Keita Ninomiya. While the plot is slightly lopsided, Kore-eda's sensitive touch and exploration of themes like identity and family make for a poignant and accessible film.

site_title: Study on next batch of LNG supplies almost completed
summary: Singapore's Energy Market Authority (EMA) is set to announce plans for the next liquefied natural gas purchase tranche later this week. The study, which began after BG Group's initial purchase, is nearly completed. The regulator aims to source future LNG supplies, particularly as BG Group reaches its franchised volume of three million tonnes per annum. Details of the plans are expected to be shared with the public soon.

site_title: Triyards, Ezion clinch new marine deals
summary: Triyards and Ezion secured new marine deals worth US$59 million and up to US$65 million, respectively. Triyards landed its tenth self-elevating unit order with an Asian client, while Ezion received a letter of intent for a service rig contract with a potential value of up to US$65 million. The deals are expected to boost Triyards' net order book to US$217 million.

site_title: Petra Foods' sweet deal hits sour note
summary: Petra Foods' cocoa ingredients business is being sold to Barry Callebaut for $950 million, subject to adjustments. However, the buyer is now seeking a $98.3 million price reduction, which could result in a 20% decrease in the original offer price. This could lead to a potential net loss of 6 US cents per share, down from a previously estimated net gain of 10 US cents per share. Petra Foods has disputed the price reduction, stating that it is not compliant with the sale agreement and the law.

site_title: Govt to launch electricity futures market trial next year
summary: Singapore plans to launch an electricity futures market trial in the second half of 2014, with the goal of ensuring competitive electricity prices. The market will allow independent retailers to hedge against price fluctuations, promoting retail competition and benefiting consumers. Additionally, the government is considering an electricity demand response scheme, where consumers can curb demand when prices are high, to moderate price spikes and generate system-wide savings. The demand response scheme is expected to be implemented in 2015.

site_title: Viva Industrial Trust could exceed projected yields
summary: Viva Industrial Trust (VIT) may exceed its projected yield of 8.81-9.48% due to tax transparency in its UE BizHub East arrangement, according to its managers. The trust, comprising business parks, has seen significant interest in its IPO, with 211.7 million units offered at 78 cents per stapled security. The business park component constitutes 77.6% of VIT's portfolio, offering good potential for steady returns. The trust's managers are confident of achieving its projected yields prior to Q1's payout.

site_title: Business loans drive growth in bank lending
summary: Business loans in Singapore increased 1.1% to $546.6 billion in September, driven by growth in the general commerce and business services sectors. Consumer loans, however, grew only 0.6% to $220.9 billion, largely due to government macroprudential measures to curb excessive consumer leverage. Economists expect the trend to continue, with business loans expected to accelerate and consumer loans to remain stable. The divergence between corporate and consumer loans is seen as a positive development, with business optimism and attractive lending rates contributing to the growth.

site_title: Three-Minute Digest
summary: Singapore Exchange considers offering rebates to high-frequency market makers to boost liquidity. Straits Trading Company partners with a Li Ka-shing fund management firm to form an investment company. The government is committed to encouraging entrepreneurship despite focusing on SME solutions. A trial for Singapore's electricity futures market is set to launch next year. Private home prices decreased in September, while the ringgit reached a six-month high after a credible budget. China's brokerages are optimistic about repo rates, and Seoul is considering shifting from nuclear power amid a scandal. European managers signal signs of growth.

site_title: Myanmar's aviation sector booming
summary: Myanmar's aviation sector is experiencing rapid growth, with passenger numbers surging as new airlines and foreign carriers enter the market. However, the industry faces significant safety concerns, with nine times the global average air accident rate. The country's antiquated and under-funded airports are also struggling to cope with the increased demand. Despite efforts to upgrade infrastructure, including a planned $1.5 billion airport for Yangon, concerns remain about the sector's readiness for the pace of change. Experts warn that the industry risks being "choked up" due to inadequate infrastructure and safety measures.

site_title: SGX mulls over rebates for high-frequency market makers
summary: Singapore Exchange (SGX) is considering rebates for high-frequency market makers to boost liquidity in its marketplace. The exchange aims to support liquidity and compensate traders for their cost and risk. SGX plans to implement circuit breakers in 2014 and invests in low-latency technology. The move comes as Singapore's single-exchange market lacks opportunities for high-frequency traders to arbitrage price differences. SGX may also consider lowering clearing fees or reducing clearing charges if traded volumes exceed a certain threshold.

site_title: Figtree Holdings seeks $12m in IPO share placement
summary: Figtree Holdings has priced its $12 million initial public offering (IPO) at 22 cents per share, representing 20% of its enlarged share capital. The company, which designs and builds commercial and industrial facilities, has seen significant growth in its net profit and revenue, with a 42% increase in revenue for the first half of FY2013. Figtree aims to use the IPO proceeds to undertake property development projects, expand operations, and finance the purchase of a new office. The company expects to sustain its business in the long run, but acknowledges that the profit increase may not be sustainable.

site_title: Corporate bonds attractive again, reaching new peaks
summary: Singapore corporate bonds have reached new highs as investors seek yields amid concerns of delayed US Federal Reserve tapering. The Markit iBoxx SGD Corporates Index surged 2.8% to a record high, driven by perpetual bonds yielding up to 6.016%. Experts say the market rally is reminiscent of last year's fourth quarter, with many chasing returns and seeking higher yields. However, some caution that Fed tapering has only been postponed and may be imminent, prompting investors to rebalance their portfolios towards shorter duration issues.

site_title: Communication is key in penny regulation
summary: Regulators can effectively manage market volatility by using verbal signals and threats to calm markets without resorting to action. The US Federal Reserve and European Central Bank have used communication strategies to reassure markets, while the Singapore Exchange (SGX) could have done the same with stronger signals in the recent penny stock fiasco. Regulators play a crucial role in shaping investor expectations and attitudes, and clear communication is essential to maintain market integrity, preventing unusually large price swings that can dominate headlines.

site_title: Orchestrating tableau of big data
summary: Tableau Software, founded by three Stanford engineers in 2003, is poised to capitalize on the growing demand for big data analytics. The company's software helps businesses make sense of vast amounts of data, and its revenue has grown significantly, reaching $127.7 million in 2012. With the increasing importance of big data, companies like SAP and McKinsey predict a $220 billion and $325 billion impact, respectively. Tableau aims to be the data crunching tool for everyone, offering an agnostic solution to cover various data sources, and has seen rapid expansion, with 930 employees globally.

site_title: Japan's NTT pays US$875m for two US cloud computing firms
summary: NTT Communications agreed to pay US$875 million for two US-based cloud computing firms, Virtela and 80% stake in RagingWire, to boost its ability to supply online access to software and data storage for big global clients. The deal comes as NTT looks to counter a slowdown in its mainstay long-distance telecom business and aims to counter unfavourable demographics in Japan. The acquisition is expected to more than double NTT's data centre space in the US, enabling the company to respond to high demand for data centre services.

site_title: The stability of the Singapore dollar
summary: The stability of the Singapore dollar is a key factor in its appeal as a listing destination for Asean-focused companies. A comparison of equity indices over the last six months in local currency and US dollar terms showed that Singapore's share market measures up well against most regional markets in US dollar terms. This reduced currency risk makes Singapore an attractive location for companies to list and investors seeking regional exposure. The city-state's stable currency is a significant advantage, setting it apart from neighboring countries.

site_title: Straits Trading in $294m ARA deal
summary: Straits Trading Company (STC) has entered into a $294.4 million deal to buy a 20.1% stake in Cheung Kong-related real estate fund manager ARA Asset Management, with a strategic tie-up allowing STC to seed and grow its property holdings. The deal values ARA at $1.7326 per share, and STC will set up a 90/10 co-investment company, Straits Real Estate, with ARA's CEO John Lim, aiming to invest up to $950 million. The partnership aims to transform STC's low-yielding assets into higher-return investments.

site_title: Royal Caribbean lifts earnings forecast
summary: Royal Caribbean Cruises raised its full-year earnings forecast due to increased demand in Europe and Asia, beating Wall Street estimates. The company reported higher bookings for 2014 in most markets, signaling a revival in the cruise industry. Despite negative publicity from recent mishaps, Royal Caribbean cut prices to revive demand, with prices remaining steady for the first quarter and trending higher for the following quarters. The company raised its full-year adjusted earnings forecast to $2.30-2.35 per share, beating estimates, and reported a 3% increase in net yields for 2013.

site_title: Nod for proposed listing of Frasers Centrepoint
summary: Frasers Centrepoint Limited (FCL) has received Singapore Exchange (SGX) approval for its planned listing, with F&N to distribute two shares in FCL for each F&N share held by investors. The move is part of F&N's plan to shed its property arm and focus on its food and beverage business. FCL, with a portfolio of residential, commercial, and hospitality assets, will become one of the biggest property plays on SGX after listing, with a market capitalization of about $10.5 billion.

site_title: Staying neutral pays off for Informatica
summary: Informatica Corporation, a Nasdaq-listed technology firm, is remaining agnostic in the data tech industry, prioritizing compatibility with various tech products over vendor-driven product stacks. The company has hit a record $811.6 million in annual revenues and is diversifying its product portfolio to cater to the growing demand for big data. Informatica's focus on accessibility is expected to appeal to small and medium-sized businesses, driving growth in Asia, particularly in the Asia-Pacific region, where big data-related product spending is expected to grow by 42.6% this year.

site_title: SIA cuts non-stop all-business NY flights
summary: Singapore Airlines is retiring its non-stop, all-business class flights from Singapore to Newark, New Jersey, due to high and volatile fuel prices making ultra-long haul operations unprofitable.
