New ship orders are also prompting concerns about another glut upon delivery in 18 months.

site_title: Company Briefs
summary: Yangzijiang Shipbuilding secured US$871 million in orders for 12 bulk carriers and five containerships. The Monetary Authority of Singapore, Malaysia, and Thailand signed an agreement to facilitate cross-border offering of collective investment schemes to retail investors. Jaya Holdings delivered a new vessel to a charterer in East Africa. Capital Tower's 25th floor was partially flooded due to a water valve, disrupting office access. Auditors EY warned Asian Micro Holdings may not be able to continue as a going concern due to significant losses and liabilities.

site_title: Singapore fund investors still cautious: Eastspring Investments
summary: Singapore unit trust investors prefer income over growth for the next six months, with 31% allocating to income funds and 28% to growth funds, according to a survey by Eastspring Investments. Investors are most confident in equities, with 50% expressing confidence, while real estate and bonds saw lower forward confidence. The preference is for higher-yielding equity funds within income funds, indicating investors remain cautious and seek income protection. This trend is in line with the region but slightly more income-focused, with a score of 43 on a scale of zero to 100.

site_title: Dubai could shut int'l airport to boost super-hub
summary: Dubai International Airport may be shut to boost traffic at the new Al Maktoum super-hub, which is being expanded to handle 200 million passengers a year. If two hubs hamper take-up, the airport authority could find alternative uses for the prime real estate. Al Maktoum, set to open on October 27, has attracted only one client, Wizz Air, and talks are underway with three more potential customers. The airport's capacity may be reduced if it operates two hubs, and Dubai Airports is accelerating construction of Al Maktoum to persuade Emirates to move in by 2025.

site_title: Foreign investor interest in Westports intense
summary: Foreign investors are showing intense interest in Westports Holdings, a Malaysian port operator, ahead of its RM2.12 billion initial public offering (IPO) later this month. The high demand has led to the order books being closed ahead of schedule, with shares priced at RM2.50 apiece. This enthusiasm is expected to boost other firms planning to list, including UMW Oil & Gas Corporation and Iskandar Waterfront, potentially making this year Malaysia's top destination for listings.

images.alt_text: No turning back: Westports is controlled by Malaysian tycoon G Gnanalingam. - PHOTO: REUTERS

site_title: Firms' anti-graft rules good in theory: EY poll
summary: A survey by Ernst & Young found that 59% of Singapore executives believe that their companies' anti-bribery and anti-corruption policies are good in theory, but do not work well in practice. The survey, which polled 681 executives across the Asia-Pacific region, also found that Singapore lagged the regional average in training and management commitment to ABAC policies. Only 18% of Singapore respondents said their management strongly communicated their commitment to ABAC policies, and 14% said they had received annual training on the policies.

site_title: Looking for more clarity in Fed talk
summary: Federal Reserve Chairman Ben Bernanke's announcement that the central bank wouldn't immediately begin tapering its asset purchases was met with criticism from 33 of 48 economists polled, citing the Fed's unclear communications. Despite the market's initial rally, economists argue that the Fed's actions were a surprise to many professional investors, who had bet on a September taper. The Fed's efforts to manage market expectations are complicated by its operating in largely uncharted territory, and economists suggest that more communication is needed to avoid confusion.

site_title: Baltimore cargo in a jam as port workers walk off
summary: Baltimore's port was closed after 2,000 union longshoremen walked off the job in a contract dispute, affecting auto shipments from Mazda Motor Corp and Bayerische Motoren Werke AG. The closure puts pressure on the auto supply chain, with Mazda set to ship 65,000 vehicles a year and Fiat SpA shipping 30,000 autos. The dispute centers on a contract signed by the International Longshoremen's Association, which was rejected by a local union, and negotiations between the union and the Steamship Trade Association. A resolution is hoped for within the next day or two to minimize economic impact.

site_title: Sembcorp pumping 932m yuan into China plant
summary: Sembcorp Industries is investing 932 million yuan (S$190 million) in its first comprehensive total water management plant in China, supporting a coal-to-diesel project in Shanxi province. The plant, located in Wangqiao Industrial Park, will operate on a 'closed loop' water management system, treating industrial wastewater and reclaiming water for reuse. The project is part of Sembcorp's expansion into the coal-to-chemical sector and marks the company's 23rd utilities operation in China.

site_title: Warm reception expected for Westwood EC site
summary: A 99-year leasehold residential site in Lorong Lew Lian is unlikely to be triggered soon, with consultants predicting a top land bid of between $430 and $490 per square foot per plot ratio (psf ppr) if launched next year. In contrast, the executive condominium (EC) site in Westwood Avenue is expected to be warmly received, with pricing expectations ranging from $285 to $380 psf ppr. The Westwood site, spanning 186,052 sq ft, is expected to yield 980 housing units, with consultants citing pent-up demand and favorable market conditions as drivers of the bullish expectations.

site_title: COE premiums fall across the board
summary: COE premiums in Singapore have fallen across the board after a strong surge two weeks ago. Category A certificates for cars below 1,600cc dropped $8,111 to $76,889, while Cat B for cars above 1,600cc slipped $5,590 to $87,910. Cat E, the open category, decreased $1,600 to $92,289. The managing director of a luxury dealership attributed the correction to the saturated luxury market and expected a rebound in premiums for Cat A and Cat B.

site_title: Plane sales stall as US shutdown continues
summary: The US government shutdown is affecting the aviation industry, with hundreds of sales stalled due to the Federal Aviation Administration's (FAA) aircraft-registration office remaining closed. The shutdown, now in its 11th day, is causing economic ripple effects, with US$2.5 billion in jetliners, small planes, and helicopters potentially in limbo. Major companies, including Airbus and Boeing, are concerned about delivery delays and the impact on their operations, with some deliveries already being put on hold. The FAA has stated that it cannot operate the registry and other non-life-safety operations during the shutdown.

site_title: Global air cargo traffic may grow at 4.8% per year
summary: Global air cargo traffic is projected to grow at 4.8% per year for the next two decades, nearly doubling the global freighter fleet to 3,000 aircraft by 2032. Airbus forecasts a need for 2,700 new and converted aircraft, with the Asia-Pacific region accounting for 42% of global cargo traffic by 2032. Mid-size freighters will dominate the market, increasing from 744 to 1,290 units, while large freighters will reach 1,000 units and small freighters will decline from 23% to 21%.

site_title: The latest toy for the rich: personal submersibles
summary: A Dutch company, U-Boat Worx, is assembling personal submersibles that can carry three people up to 914.4 meters beneath the waves, targeting wealthy yacht owners. These submersibles, costing between $1 million and $4 million, allow passengers to explore the ocean without scuba diving certification or getting wet. They feature amenities like leather seats, iPod docking stations, and hydrophones to listen to sea creatures. The industry, largely unregulated, has raised safety concerns, but companies voluntarily submit their submersibles to rating and require training for pilots and crew.

site_title: Boustead secures $38m in oil & gas sector contracts
summary: Boustead Singapore secured $38 million in oil & gas sector contracts, surpassing the $300 million mark for the fiscal year 2014. The energy-related engineering division's order backlog now stands at $523 million. The contracts are for waste heat recovery units and process heater systems in Norway and Russia, with no expected material impact on the company's profitability. Revenue for the first quarter was $128.7 million, a year-on-year increase of 14%, and net profit was $17.7 million, a 45% increase.

site_title: Singapore market a source of funds for junk bond issuers
summary: Singapore's high-yield bond market has attracted companies in South-east Asia, with a record $5 billion in deals so far this year. Companies such as Rajawali Group and Indofood Agri Resources are using Singapore as an alternative to the US dollar market due to lower coupon rates. However, a recent transaction by Perisai Petroleum showed that even yield-hungry Singapore investors are hesitant to take on unknown foreign issuers, with the company raising only $23 million of three-year bonds. Despite this, bankers believe the market remains reliable, with demand for recognisable names.

site_title: Asia's art market heats up anew
summary: Asia's art market is experiencing a resurgence, with Christie's and Sotheby's selling US$700 million worth of artwork in recent days in Hong Kong, setting world records. Chinese rivals Poly and Guardian have seen significant growth due to their freedom to operate within China and their political connections. Despite being barred from selling antiques, Western firms are focusing on contemporary art and seeking to expand demand. Chinese companies are now seeking to challenge foreign competitors outside the mainland, with Poly opening an office in New York.

site_title: Confident or overconfident?
summary: Shipping industry confidence levels have held firm, with the average confidence rating reaching 5.9 on a 10-point scale, according to a recent survey by Moore Stephens. Charterers' confidence reached a three-year high, while owners and managers also showed increased optimism. The survey also found that operating costs fell by 1.8% last year, but insurance costs dropped by 6% due to reduced ship values. However, concerns about overcapacity and the impact of regulation persist, and some experts warn that the recent upswing in confidence may be short-lived.

site_title: QE3 and tapering issues not settled yet
summary: The US Federal Reserve's decision not to taper its $85 billion monthly QE3 monetary stimulus program has sent mixed signals to investors, partly due to the partial US government shutdown. The Fed's communication policy has been effective in supporting Wall Street, but its failure to provide clear guidance on tapering has created uncertainty. Yale University's Stephen Roach argues that QE is destabilizing and ineffective, citing small wealth effects that mostly benefit the wealthy. Investors should prepare for the issues related to QE3 to resurface once the government shutdown is resolved.

site_title: Debt servicing rule dents prices, volumes
summary: Singapore's private property prices rose 0.4% in Q3, according to URA flash estimates, despite the Total Debt Servicing Ratio (TDSR) framework, which has been cooling the market. However, certain segments, such as Core Central Region (CCR) and city-fringe homes, saw price declines. Transaction volumes dropped across all market segments, with CCR and RCR seeing significant declines. Experts expect OCR prices to continue moderating, while CCR and RCR prices may show a gradual softening trend. Overall, private residential home prices are expected to flat line in Q4 and register a mild increase for the whole of 2013.

site_title: Eu Yan Sang posts Q1 net of $1.43m
summary: Eu Yan Sang International reported a Q1 net profit of $1.43 million, up from $341,000 last year, driven by 13% higher revenue and lower foreign exchange losses. Revenue came from retail ($60.15m), wholesale ($13.99m), and TCM clinics ($4.46m). Earnings per share rose to 0.32 cents, and operating profit surged 48% to $4.64 million. The company expects modest economic growth and incremental sales growth, with core business remaining profitable.

site_title: Markets unfazed by partial US shutdown
summary: The US federal government partially shut down for the first time since 1996 due to a budget impasse. Markets were largely unaffected, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average and Standard & Poor's 500 index rising. The partial shutdown weakened the dollar, sending it to an eight-month low against the euro. Economists warned that a prolonged shutdown would drain spending from the economy and rattle confidence, but investors appeared to take the news in stride.

site_title: Brazil fire razes major world sugar terminal
summary: A fire at Copersucar's sugar terminal in Brazil's Santos port has crippled the world's largest sugar trader, paralyzing operations and putting 10 million tonnes of export capacity offline for six months or more. The blaze destroyed nearly all of Copersucar's warehouses, sparking a global price spike to a one-year high, and leaving the company scrambling to lease or rent terminal space. The fire will likely benefit Copersucar's rivals and send global sugar prices soaring, with prices rising more than 6% on news of the fire.

images.alt_text: Huge melt-down: A fire fighter struggling to put out the fire at the sugar warehouse in the Brazilian port of Santos on Friday. - PHOTO: REUTERS

site_title: OSIM's Q3 net profit rises 16% to $22.7m
summary: OSIM International reported a 16% increase in its third-quarter net profit to $22.7 million, driven by improved sales of massage chairs, massagers, and nutritional supplements. Revenue rose 7% to $153 million, with North Asian operations contributing 9% to the total. The company plans to add 6-10 outlets in North Asia and enhance its products, including the uInfinity chair, in the coming year. Net profit for the first nine months of the year was $74 million, up 15% year-over-year.

site_title: StarHub customers get fire-fallout freebies too
summary: StarHub and SingTel have offered compensation to customers affected by a fire at SingTel's Bukit Panjang Exchange, which disrupted services. StarHub customers received one month of free TV viewing, a waived subscription fee for Digital Voice customers, and a $10 supermarket voucher. SingTel offered three months' free speed boost, free channel surfing, and free local calls. The Infocomm Development Authority of Singapore is investigating the fire, which damaged 149 fibre cables and affected customers of StarHub and M1.

site_title: Demand for cargo carriers up 3.6% globally
summary: Global air freight demand grew 3.6% in August, driven by improving business confidence in Europe and the US. However, capacity outpaced demand, resulting in a freight load factor of 42.8%. The Asia-Pacific region saw a 0.2% contraction, while European and Middle-Eastern carriers drove growth, with demand up 3.4% and 23.8%, respectively. Latin-American carriers also posted strong growth, while North American airlines saw 0.7% growth in volumes. IATA CEO Tony Tyler noted that the air freight business remains tough, with revenues expected to reach $59 billion this year, down from $67 billion in 2011.

site_title: Pay hikes in region seen holding steady
summary: Pay hikes in Singapore and the Asia-Pacific region are expected to hold steady at 5.0% in 2014, with bonuses likely to rise to 16% of total pay, up from 15% this year. The tight labor market and higher inflation are driving these predictions, with some employers offering salary increases of up to 6.0% in the financial sector. Only three markets are expected to see higher salary increases, with the rest experiencing pay hikes that will remain stagnant or decrease slightly.

site_title: Bureau Veritas opens deepwater tech research hub
summary: Bureau Veritas has opened its Deepwater Technology Research Centre (DTRC) in Singapore, supported by the Maritime and Port Authority of Singapore's Maritime Cluster Fund. The DTRC aims to provide advanced technical solutions and innovations to BV's clients in Asia-Pacific, enhancing its real-time support. This is the first BV technology research centre in Asia, and it will benefit from the expanded MCF, which supports the setting up of R&D and test centres.
